notes:
1. Definition

Axial deformation is the change in length of a member when it is subjected to a tensile or compressive axial force (a force acting along its longitudinal axis). Tensile forces cause the member to elongate, while compressive forces cause it to shorten.

2. Formula for Elastic Deformation

Within the elastic limit of the material, the deformation ($\delta$) of a prismatic member (one with a constant cross-section) is given by the formula:

$$ \delta = \frac{PL}{AE} $$
  • $\delta$: Total deformation (change in length).
  • $P$: Applied axial load.
  • $L$: Original length of the member.
  • $A$: Cross-sectional area of the member.
  • $E$: Modulus of Elasticity (Young's Modulus) of the material, a measure of its stiffness.

The term $AE/L$ is often referred to as the axial stiffness of the member.

solvedExamples.question: A steel rod is 10 feet long and has a cross-sectional area of 0.5 in². It is subjected to a tensile force of 10,000 lbs. If the Modulus of Elasticity for steel is 29,000,000 psi, what is the total elongation of the rod?
solvedExamples.explanation: Use the deformation formula $\delta = PL/AE$. First, ensure all units are consistent. Convert the length to inches: L = 10 ft * 12 in/ft = 120 in. Now plug in the values: $\delta = \frac{(10,000 \text{ lbs})(120 \text{ in})}{(0.5 \text{ in²})(29,000,000 \text{ lb/in²})} = \frac{1,200,000}{14,500,000} \approx 0.0828$ inches.

solvedExamples.question: A member with a constant cross-section is made of a certain material. If both the applied load and the length of the member are doubled, how does its axial deformation change?
solvedExamples.explanation: Deformation is directly proportional to both load (P) and length (L). If P becomes 2P and L becomes 2L, the new deformation will be $\delta_{new} = \frac{(2P)(2L)}{AE} = 4 \frac{PL}{AE} = 4\delta_{old}$. The deformation quadruples.
